↳ In-reply-to ¬ª After seeing some ChatGPT interactions I believe all doomsday AI scenarios are stupid and I also believe it's impossible for an intelligent creature to create a creature more intelligent than itself.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci True, there‚Äôs no argument there will be some ‚Äúutility‚Äô from these LLM(s) ‚Äì It will be even more useful when most folks can run them (maybe at a smaller scale) on ‚Äúedge‚Äù computing on modest hardware.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I tend to agree with you, and it's one of the reasons why I did evolutionary computation in my PhD. My PhD advisor was big on the idea that even though we don't know what life or intelligence is well enough to make it from scratch, maybe we can set up an artificial world in which (simulated) life can "emerge" from the primordial soup, so to speak. I thought that idea was pretty compelling and I worked on it for awhile. It's why I, too, and frustrated by the term "AI" and how it's slapped onto anything these days. Some of the stuff that people call AI right now would have been called "an algorithm" or "a computer program" not so long ago üòÜ

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci It‚Äôs actually one of the aspects of the ‚Äúfamily of machine learning‚Äù that I find the most intriguing. If you‚Äôve ever played the game Creates (I haven‚Äôt, but know a lot about it), it was an amazing piece of work. I‚Äôd love to work on something like this one day or see something like it at a much larger scale üëå

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª After seeing some ChatGPT interactions I believe all doomsday AI scenarios are stupid and I also believe it's impossible for an intelligent creature to create a creature more intelligent than itself.

Wake me up when we can run these LLM(s) and similar models on the energy requirements of a Raspberry Pi ü§£

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª After seeing some ChatGPT interactions I believe all doomsday AI scenarios are stupid and I also believe it's impossible for an intelligent creature to create a creature more intelligent than itself.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Oh I don‚Äôt accept the marketing hype at all. The thing that I always fall back on is the insane amount of power that it takes to runs these fuckings tupid ass models that are nothing more than (okay admittedly a bit fancier than the ones a few decades ago, but mostly based on the same mechanics) ‚Äúalgorithms‚Äù that take data in and spit data out. The shocking part for me is comparing the insane power and energy requirements of even the largest ‚ÄúAI‚Äù models in the world and comparing that with the energy/power requirements of running (for example) the brain of a rat.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª After seeing some ChatGPT interactions I believe all doomsday AI scenarios are stupid and I also believe it's impossible for an intelligent creature to create a creature more intelligent than itself.

@bender True and good points, my only gripe though we should call it what it really is üòÖ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª After seeing some ChatGPT interactions I believe all doomsday AI scenarios are stupid and I also believe it's impossible for an intelligent creature to create a creature more intelligent than itself.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci You are right of course. I don‚Äôt think we can consider anything thus are to be remotely close to ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù, it actually frustrates me that we can call these fields ‚ÄúAI‚Äù, we should call them what they are, ‚Äúmachine learning‚Äù, they‚Äôre just fancy algorithms many of which are pretty good at ‚Äúpattern matching‚Äù.

As for what we define as ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù, fucked if I know üòÖ I doubt anyone else can define this either. I tend to believe that until we figure out how to create ‚Äúsomething‚Äù that can have a sense of self-awareness and self-growth and a way to expand and ‚Äúreprogram‚Äù itself, we‚Äôll never get very far. Really ‚Äúevolutionary life‚Äù simulations or ‚Äúartificial life simulations‚Äù are much closer I think.
